awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying Sediment Sources and Routing of Transcontinental Drainages During Intraplate Deformation
awd_abstract_narration:
The largest rivers in the world often start in mountain ranges on one side of a continent and bring sediment to deltas on the opposite side of the continent.  The factors that allow these long-lived rivers to maintain or re-establish their courses in the face of changing geological conditions are largely unexplored.  This project will study how transcontinental rivers change with time in response to the formation of mountain ranges or basins in the rivers' pathways.  Understanding how rivers respond: whether they find a way through or around the developing mountains or basins, and how quickly they re-establish their prior courses, is critical to accurately interpreting the sedimentary record in their deltas.  In addition to providing greater insight into continental-scale rivers, this project will provide STEM training for graduate and undergraduate students and support research infrastructure and analytical facilities at a large state university and a small private university.  Further, the project will provide an opportunity for hands-on STEM training for ~30 middle school students per year under the guidance of a university professor.   

Research will focus on the "Ancestral Rocky Mountains" (ARM) and associated basins, which developed primarily in Utah, Colorado, Texas, and New Mexico 320-280 million years ago.  These basins archive changes associated with disruption and reintegration of a continental-scale river in response to ARM evolution.  This project will combine traditional and cutting-edge methods including field observations of sedimentary strata, U-Pb radiometric dating, analysis of Hf isotopes, and (U-Th)/He radiometric dating of zircons and monazite minerals in sandstones and igneous rocks to determine where sediment came from and how it changed through time.  In addition, (U-Th)/He radiometric dating on zircon minerals in igneous rocks will be used to determine when the mountain ranges developed.  These data will link changes in sediment sources to mountain and basin development through time. This will be augmented by development of new software to help determine the sources, and proportion of each source, for sediment based on radiometric dating of minerals in sandstones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on improving our understanding of the Ancestral Rocky Mountains, an enigmatic series of ancient mountain ranges that were located in modern day Oklahoma, Colorado, Utah, and New Mexico. The tectonic mechanism that caused these uplifts is debated, and improved records of the timing and magnitude of these uplifts are needed to test competing hypotheses. We collected rock samples from the easternmost of these uplifts, the Wichita-Amarillo uplift in Oklahoma, and measured the abundances of particular isotopes that are sensitive to the temperatures experienced by a rock. Numerical modeling of these results reveal a complex geologic history for this Ancestral Rocky Mountains block. Surface uplift began around 325 million years ago, leading to intense erosion that ultimately exposed rocks that were once at a depth of about 5 km at the surface. In time, erosion completely wore down this topography and the area was buried by sediment in a shallow sea, ultimately reaching a depth of 2-3 km by around 100 million years ago.

The research also supported the development of a new approach to reconstruct the directions and magnitude of tectonic stresses that squeezed rocks like those in the Ancestral Rocky Mountains. Some minerals, such as calcite, respond to pressure by forming deformation twins, which are domains of a crystal in which atoms are systematically displaced to enable a change in shape. We mapped the orientation of both calcite crystals and their twins using an advanced technique, electron backscatter diffraction, in which an electron beam is focused on a slice of a rock sample. We developed new algorithms that can analyze these datasets to estimate the direction and size of the stresses active when the rocks were being deformed and uplifted.

This project also supported substantive scientific training and mentorship for four undergraduate researchers. The students gained confidence and developed important skills by actively contributing to all aspects of the research, including conducting fieldwork, preparing samples, operating the scanning electron microscope, assisting in data analysis, and reading and discussing scientific literature. Two students authored abstracts for presentation at national scientific conferences.
